title: 104_hr2654
content: The Act is titled the "Victims of Abuse Insurance Protection Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Victims of Abuse Insurance Protection Act" defines abuse as acts causing bodily injury, emotional distress, rape, or engaging in conduct that instills fear of harm. The "Victims of Abuse Insurance Protection Act" defines abuse as causing bodily injury, emotional distress, false imprisonment, kidnapping, or damage to property to intimidate or control behavior. Abuse-related medical condition refers to a medical condition resulting from abuse, while abuse status pertains to being a subject of abuse. A health benefit plan is any entity providing payments for health services. A health benefit plan includes group health plans, health insurance arrangements, and workers' compensation related to medical benefits. The term "health carrier" refers to a person who contracts to provide health care services on a risk-assuming basis. An "insured" is a party named on a policy or health benefit plan with legal rights to the benefits. A beneficiary is covered by a group policy, certificate, or health benefit plan. An insurer includes various entities engaged in insurance business. A policy is a contract of insurance issued by an insurer. The subject of abuse is a person targeted by an act of abuse. A person targeted by an act of abuse may have prior injuries, illnesses, or disorders resulting from abuse, or may have sought medical or psychological treatment for protection. SEC. 3. DISCRIMINATORY ACTS PROHIBITED. No insurer or health carrier may engage in discriminatory acts against individuals who are, have been, or may be the subject of abuse, including denying insurance coverage, restricting benefits for abuse-related losses, or adding a premium differential. No insurer can discriminate against individuals who are victims of abuse by terminating their health coverage if it was originally issued in the name of the abuser and the abuser no longer has custody or coverage. The insurer can require the victim to pay the full premium and may terminate group coverage after 18 months if conversion to an equivalent plan is offered. The continuation of health coverage for abuse victims is required for 18 months if conversion to an equivalent plan is offered. No insurer can use or disclose information about an applicant's abuse status or related medical condition. The applicant's abuse status or related medical condition cannot be used or disclosed by insurers unless required by law. A subject of abuse can provide evidence for treatment purposes. The paragraph states that insurers cannot use an applicant's abuse-related condition unless required by law, and evidence provided by the individual must be considered for treatment purposes. SEC. 4. An insurer must provide specific reasons in writing for any adverse action taken on a plan or policy of a subject of abuse. SEC. 5. Life insurers can decline issuing a policy if the applicant lacks insurable interest or has a history of abuse. SEC. 6. Prohibits subrogation without consent. SEC. 6 prohibits subrogation of claims resulting from abuse without the informed consent of the subject of abuse. The Federal Trade Commission has the power to investigate insurers for violations of the Act and issue cease and desist orders. Individuals affected by insurer violations can take legal action in federal court. Individuals affected by insurer violations can take legal action in federal or state court. The court may award relief, including injunctive relief, compensatory and punitive damages, costs of suit, and attorney fees. The aggrieved individual may choose to receive statutory damages of $5,000 for each violation instead of actual damages.
